pr_title: Add integration with Package Management Service

timeline.bodyText: I could be wrong, but I thought that the object mapper had a bytebuffer overload so you don't need to copy it into a byte[].

replies.bodyText: No I checked for that, not an option unfortunately.

timeline.bodyText: This is not an exception in downloading the recipe. The received recipe is of invalid format right? So I think the message should be changed indicate that.
timeline.author: abanthiy

replies.bodyText: Good catch, fixing.
replies.author: chaurah

timeline.bodyText: How does client handle timeout?
timeline.author: abanthiy

replies.bodyText: Default AWS SDK behavior for retries and timeouts (I believe it's 30 seconds and 3 retries)
replies.author: chaurah

replies.bodyText: So we expect to get a 408 response code in response here?
replies.author: abanthiy

replies.bodyText:
Handled by AmazonClientException catch block. The SDK tries to throw exceptions for almost all cases. It's only when the service returns a 2xx with some separate response code in status body that you will need explicit status code parsing. In theory. Heavily depends on modelling.
Think LambdaInvokeResponse and LambdaProxyResponse from v1.
replies.author: chaurah

timeline.bodyText: 5XX?
timeline.author: abanthiy

replies.bodyText: None yet, service only returns the above. Still WIP from their side.
replies.author: chaurah

timeline.bodyText:
Why is there no client in the name of this type? Is this standard?
This is a REST client I believe?
timeline.author: abanthiy

replies.bodyText: WIP client, subject to change if the service client changes. I would except the final client is just called AWSGreengrassClient
replies.author: chaurah

Add integration with Package Management Service

timeline.bodyText: For unit testing keep this package private if possible.
timeline.author: MikeDombo

replies.bodyText: Makes sense, going to check if doable.
replies.author: chaurah

timeline.bodyText: Never seen this before, is this from the new client or is this in our code?
timeline.author: MikeDombo

replies.bodyText: New for us, discovered it myself while working on this PR. Located here : https://github.com/aws/aws-greengrass-kernel/blob/1f1808f9175d3b22169286e4c309d6a628d7490f/src/main/java/com/aws/iot/evergreen/util/SerializerFactory.java
replies.author: chaurah

replies.bodyText: Better if renaming it to RECIPE_SERIALIZER because it is configured as an recipe serializer.
replies.author: leaf94

replies.bodyText: Makes sense, updating
replies.author: chaurah

timeline.bodyText: We should be able to avoid creating this. Let's sync up offline.
timeline.author: leaf94

replies.bodyText: Removed
replies.author: chaurah

timeline.bodyText:
Try only the line
GetPackageResult getPackageResult = evgPmsClient.getPackage(getPackageRequest);

for catching exceptions for calling PMS.
Then try parsing logic for handling parsing/loading exception.
timeline.author: leaf94

replies.bodyText: Split the two basically? Sounds good
replies.author: chaurah

timeline.bodyText: No need to implement fully but what about Service Exception?
timeline.author: leaf94

replies.bodyText: Service Exception is child of client exception. When we have a stable sdk, we can expand into various handlers, didn't seem warranted at the moment.
replies.author: chaurah

replies.bodyText: I'm referring to AmazonServiceException. Other than catching client exception, which indicates error in java client, we should probably also catch AmazonServiceException to handle error from service side.
replies.author: leaf94

replies.bodyText:
yes, that's a child of the client exception. Ideally the SDK should specify exceptions to be caught in the service model. There are some but the model is not complete yet. The hierarchy is
AmazonClientException <- AmazonServiceException <- Service model defined exceptions.
As mentioned, I can break down into catching specific exceptions, I just don't see the point at the moment with the service and service models not fully implemented yet.
replies.author: chaurah

timeline.bodyText: Let's not check this in, shall we? Cloud team should be able to return a 200 instead of 302 easily...
timeline.author: leaf94

replies.bodyText: There's going to be an api discussion, will take time. I think the preferred approach will be to see if we can improve the default auto-generated behavior and not throw an exception. Either way will take 2-3 weeks while they're working on the service code, no point holding off on this.
replies.author: chaurah

replies.bodyText: If it is 2-3 weeks, then let's merge this in. Maybe I'm missing some context, but getArtifact should just return 200. Even if is returning a "redirectUrl", but has nothing to do with returning a 302 for this API... I think it could be easily communicated with them.
replies.author: leaf94

replies.bodyText: They had a design reviewed for the API already. I obviously already communicated the issue to them, but in the end they have to reach the stage where they will be implementing the API in the first place. Sending you the API design doc for reference :)
replies.author: chaurah

timeline.author: leaf94

replies.bodyText: Tried that, need spy because of the connection object responses. I can do the other one though probably, but felt kinda redundant to mock.
replies.author: chaurah

timeline.bodyText: If we do getPackage(any()) here, we need to verify the argument to ensure client is called with the argument we expect.
timeline.author: leaf94

replies.bodyText: Can improve that, need a captor. Sounds good.
replies.author: chaurah
